text_run.content: index is used to speed up metafiltering by a specific non-vector field value, similar to a traditional database index. This guide will walk you through creating and configuring scalar indexes for fields such as integers, strings, etc.
: Milvus automatically decides the index type based on the data type of the scalar field. This is suitable when you do not need to control the specific index type.
: You specify the exact index type, such as an inverted index. This provides more control over the index type selection.
To use auto indexing, omit the
parameter so that Milvus can infer the index type based on the scalar field type. For mappings between scalar data types and default indexing algorithms, refer to

_index_params() # Prepare an empty IndexParams object, without having to specify any index parameters

index_params.add_index(
    field_name="scalar_1", # Name of the scalar field to be indexed
="", # Type of index to be created. For auto indexing, leave it empty or omit this parameter.

index_name="default_index" # Name of the index to be created
)

client.create_index(
  collection_name="test_scalar_index", # Specify the collection name
  index_params=index_params
// Name of the scalar field to be indexed
// Name of the index to be created
// Type of index to be created. For auto indexing, leave it empty or omit this parameter.
// Name of the scalar field to be indexed
// Name of the index to be created
// Type of index to be created. For auto indexing, leave it empty or omit this parameter.
To use custom indexing, specify a particular index type in the

_index_params() #  Prepare an IndexParams object

index_params.add_index(
    field_name="scalar_2", # Name of the scalar field to be indexed
    index_type="INVERTED", # Type of index to be created
    index_name="inverted_index" # Name of the index to be created
)

client.create_index(
  collection_name="test_scalar_index", # Specify the collection name
  index_params=index_params
The name of the scalar field to index.
The type of the scalar index to create. For implicit indexing, leave it empty or omit this parameter.
For custom indexing, valid values are:
: (Recommended) An inverted index consists of a term dictionary containing all tokenized words sorted alphabetically. For details, refer to
: Sorts scalar fields using the standard template library sort algorithm. Supports Boolean and numeric fields (e.g., INT8, INT16, INT32, INT64, FLOAT, DOUBLE).
: A tree data structure for fast prefix searches and retrievals. Supports VARCHAR fields.
The name of the scalar index to create. Each scalar field supports one index.
Creates the index in the specified collection.
The name of the collection for which the index is created.

// Name of the index to be created
// Type of index to be created

: Sorts scalar fields using the standard template library sort algorithm. Supports Boolean and numeric fields (e.g., INT8, INT16, INT32, INT64, FLOAT, DOUBLE).
: A tree data structure for fast prefix searches and retrievals. Supports VARCHAR fields.
Creates the index in the specified collection.
The name of the collection for which the index is created.

: A tree data structure for fast prefix searches and retrievals. Supports VARCHAR fields.
method to verify the creation of scalar indexes:
Currently, scalar indexing supports INT8, INT16, INT32, INT64, FLOAT, DOUBLE, BOOL, and VARCHAR data types, but not JSON and ARRAY types.
